The Meatloaf was a little different from any meatloaf I've ever had, served on top of pinto beans and spinach. At first glance it didn't look appetizing but it was very moist and flavorful. I would've liked gravy or a sauce to make it more complete but I would order it again as it is. Pumpkin creme brulee for desert was more like pudding than the custard I expected but it was also very good. 

The atmosphere was relaxed and happy. Lighting was low. We had to wait for our eyes to adjust to the candle light before we could read the menu. I heard a few people at a table near us ask for more candles so they could see the menu! 

Service was awesome. We never had to wait for anything and the waiter was always available (but didn't hover) as well as friendly & informative. We never felt rushed and the waiter didn't drop the check til we asked for it. Would definitely come back again. 

Prices are what you'd expect from a high-end resort restaurant with great food, excellent service and wonderful atmosphere. After all. that's what you're actually paying for when you order that $30 prime rib dinner, right? 

Valet parking is free if you tell them you're eating at the restaurant.

Creative, excellent food with good service, but you'll pay.  I had an amazing mascarpone (not MARscapone, dammit!) stuffed french toast.  Fascinating preparation, as it was served as a "brick" (imagine quartering a loaf of bread and then splitting it in half).  Had a honey drizzle, some luscious strawberries and real maple syrup.  Absolutely delicious.  My friend's omelet was equally as tasty.  Setting is gorgeous and service was good.  Only downside is resort pricing -- $11 for the (admittedly excellent) french toast and $4 for coffee (I passed).  Yum.

I guess it's not really the most accessible place, but Frank & Albert's is located in the Arizona Biltmore Resort & Spa and serves as one of their restaurants to their guests.  Since the other breakfast place they had was only a cafe that served baked goods, I decided to come here to have a proper breakfast.

When I asked what they recommended they immediately said "the Biltmore Benedict".  I was easily sold so I ordered one, and a coffee.

Cool thing about the coffee is they just bring you a carafe to serve yourself coffee as you please.  Not sure if this was because the waitress was lazy, but I thought it was nice.

The eggs benedict themselves were not the best.  On one hand the ham that they used was overcooked (ie. jerky).  On the other hand the english muffin was over toasted and too crispy, which kinda ruined the overall consistency.

It is a nice patio that they have to sit on, so I will give them that.  They apparently have a bird problem where birds kinda come and scavenge for food.  I didn't really mind it.

This place deserves even more than 5 stars!!! 
My fianc√© and me stayed at Biltmore resort in Phoenix for a week. We decided to get all inclusive, so we could relax at this beautiful place and have our meals there, in stead of driving around trying to find new places every day in the city. And OMG we are so happy we did it!!! The food was amazing. We both LOVED every single meal we had there and were super happy with their great service!!! Everyone working there was so nice and friendly, but our favorite was Sherri. That lady deserves all the 5 stars too 
I don't even know where to start with my food reccommendations, but if you are there for breakfast, you gotta try their french toast. It was heaven... 
I highly reccomend this place to everyone. You won't be dissapointed.

Located inside the Biltmore, this place is an awesome restaurant to meet clients or friends for lunch.  I ordered a Margherita Pizza and some Iced Tea.  The Margarita Pizza was superb!  Very good and just the right size too....not too large & not too small.  I left satisfied.  The Iced Tea was very good too....I think I drank 5 or 6 glasses!

Of course, the service was outstanding as well.  It's no wonder why there were several tables and booths with people conducting business....it's a great place for that.

Return Factor - 96%

Great place to have brunch! The Huevos Rancheros are delicious and the perfect sized-portion to hold you off until lunch and still catch a few extra games. The garden landscape is an amazing view. 

Location is a perfect spot for private business meetings. There is also a private room with great views. The inside decor is up to par of what you expect of the Biltmore and Scottsdale area. 

Recommended brunch!

If you have are staying at the Arizona Biltmore in Phoenix or just happen to be nearby, try Frank & Albert's for both a pleasant and tasty bite to eat. It is located within the Biltmore and they serve breakfast, lunch and dinner. I think you will find the menu diverse and inviting with many tempting options. The service is good and the wait staff is attentive, knowledgeable and engaging.

The last time my wife and I ate here was for lunch in May. She had the crab cake sandwich and I ordered a blackened shrimp couscous salad. I also had a glass of the Caymus Conundrum - always very drinkable.

I tried my partner's crab cake sandwich and it was delicious. It included bacon, lettuce and tomato. The sea salt fries are one of my favorites. My shrimp couscous salad consisted of olives, cucumber, roasted tomato, beets with a nice vinaigrette. The shrimp were large and flavorful. 

This restaurant is a good value for your dollar and worth checking out.
Amazing!!! Love the foods and servers was friendly... will come back and stay at Az biltmore again

My in-law's were staying at the Biltmore for the weekend, so we checked out Frank and Albert's for dinner on Sunday night. 
The prices are pretty steep, but it's within a resort so you have to expect your meatloaf dinner to be over $20.
We sampled many different dishes such as the turkey meatloaf with mashed potatoes and mixed veggies within the potatoes, empanadas, pizza and the yummy and not too greasy hamburger served on an English muffin. I found the food to be very good, but a bit pricey. 
Our server Alexis was awesome! She was so friendly and made sure we had everything we needed. 
I didn't get to try any of their desserts, but everything on the dessert menu sounded delicious. 
Despite the high prices I would go back.

Came to the Biltmore for a family Staycation. Took them to F&A on our first night. We were fortunate enough to get Zach as our server (I'd had him on a previous trip out here). Wonderful service, very attentive and a charmer as well. Lots of ma'am and sirs to my hubby and I, young miss and the young gentlemen to our teenage kids. Pampered! Drinks came quickly, water and sodas refilled often. 
The food! My daughter and I split the ribeye with potato gratin. To die for, we were both in heaven! Sauce for the steak was on point, asparagus good but could have used a better trim and a touch of lemon, but that gratin is amazing. Seriously a potato and cream taken to perfection! Hubby had the cheeseburger and fries. He wasn't feeling fancy. But a d@mn decent burger with really good fries. My son was the lucky winner though, with meatloaf of all things! It had to have been 8-10 oz of meatloaf over potato pur√©e, topped with house made chipotle ketchup and fried onion strings. He had the temerity to tell ME! Me! It was better than mine! I made him give me a bite. He wasn't wrong. He wouldn't give me another bite. Jerk! I would have reconsidered my choice of ribeye if not for those potatoes gratin. 
I'm looking forward to the next few nights to explore the rest of the menu. Looking forward to the porkchop or filet mignon. Saw and smelled them as they passed. Very promising!
The food was SOOO GOOD! You cannot miss out on eating at this place.  There was never a dull moment.  The drinks were GREAT TOO!

Great happy hour deal- I got a martini for $5, and ordered from their savory bites appetizer menu (4 for $5) and got a whole bunch of food.  It's not a ton, but plenty to fill me up.  If you're starving, order a couple more regular sized appetizers for $5 each.  In any case, I was a happy camper when total bill came out to under $11.

I really love this place, but today they did not bring their "A" game. I ordered my favorite for breakfast, the Biltmore Benedict, but instead I was served an impostor with overcooked poached eggs. Service was ehh, but overall everything was just okay, and that's where the disappointment lies.

I took a couple of clients here today for lunch and was surprisingly underwhelmed for a restaurant located in such an established and beautiful hotel.   Service was adequate but the food was overpriced and just not that good.  The french dip was oversalted, but otherwise flavorless; the burger, just a burger.   I eat out almost every day due to my job, and I cannot recommend this restaurant unless you are stuck at the hotel and have no other options.

Overpriced meal options. I had the meatballs. They were burned. My mother had the meatloaf which was decent, but the sauce in top kind of ruined it. My father had the salmon and two sides. His sides were dry and looked burned. His salmon was tiny and burnt on the bottom.

Had a delightful lunch after a trip to the spa with my better half.  Service was a bit slow but good food and good drinks in a casual setting.  Definitely worth checking out if you're staying at the Biltmore or in the neighborhood.

We had great food and great drinks here twice.  The Biltmore Original is a good one.  We have visited for special occasions with a medium-sized group, and we had a great time.  The service was very good, also.

Revision: Upon receiving the bill, the server, Ines, chose to add $7.00 for spinach and a few baby tomatoes without my consent. I was very upset by this as I dine here several times per month and have never been upcharged like that. She further went on to suggest I was wrong when I told her I have never been upcharged for spinach and tomatoes! At least tell me before hand. She had no right to make that decision. 

Needless to say this is not ok. Perhaps new management choses to encourage staff to uncharge. Not cool management. 

Used to love this place. My favorite is lunch but dinner is also very very good.

I believe there is a new chef as there are a lot of new and improved dishes. 

The lunch Southwest Chicken Salad is my personal favorite. I always ask for  spinach and little baby tomatoes to be added. The dressing is a very light pineapple citrus vinaigrette. (Don't be fooled by the photo, trust me, it's light).

The Sonoran Turkey Club is also excellent.  And huge! You won't leave hungry. The bread is a house made jalape√±o infused bread. Not spicy at all but excellent flavor. 

Tip for those doing a pool day-order from F & A first and take to the pool. Better prices and better food in my opinion.

I ate here for breakfest four days in a row during my stay here.  I want to say that Sherri is by far the best server (though there was a black guy who served us one morning that was also awesome!)  There isn't a huge menu here but still you can get pretty much any breakfest food like yogurt, eggs, omelets, pancakes or a buffet.  My husband tried the Mexican pizza and although it was good it did make him sick later in the day.  Each of my times here I had the decaf coffee and it was very good!  I had the omelette twice and another day the Sonoran benedict.  The Sonoron benedict probably was my favorite item- it had eggs benedict over a pulled pork and a nice tomato salsa.  The other day I had the almond cherry foccacia french toast and it was okay.  It was a huge slab of french toast smothered with almond butter.  It was just too rich for me.  I wasn't actually a huge fan of it but it was still okay to try.  I can't speak on Frank & Albert's for lunch or dinner, but if you are staying here it was quick service and the food came out quickly as well.
Decent hotel restaurant. Good food and reasonable service but cocktails were TERRIBLY overpriced. Also beware of the beer offering, some were not really good.

Honestly the food was good, and the service was personable. Had drinks and two meals here and was real pleased with how it came out. Zee, Lisa and bartender Shawn All took very good care of us. The scallop risotto was amazing as were the sandwiches at lunch.

As a guest at the Resort we found this place to be AWESOME! The food is delicious! Happy hour bites, hamburgers,onion rings, and the mac cheese is the BOMB. We also had breakfast. They have a nice breakfast buffet, but we chose to order off the menu. Food was super fresh, and hot. We sat in the bar area, and Shane took great care of us several times. We found all the staff to be very friendly and accommodating. Highly recommended the breakfast tacos, and shredded pork eggs Benedict.
We all enjoyed our lunch here: Cobb Salad and burgers were our choices. Good food and nice friendly staff. Beautiful setting.

I came here for dinner before an event at the Biltmore. We split a few dishes. My absolute favorite was the caprese salad. It had heirloom tomatoes, balsamic vinegar, watercress, celery leaves, and burrata cheese. Burrata cheese can be hard to find friending in eegee's you live, so this was a treat. The pizza and chicken tenders were very good. The chicken tenders were most and flavorful. The service was ok. We were forgotten about after asking for a take home box. If you have a chance, give Frank and Albert's a visit!

Overpriced.... but you are at the AZ Biltmore, so you had better plan on that.  The service is great, the food is good and the establishment is awesome, especially when you consider how old it is.  I will be back!!!

Fabulous breakfast here on Sunday morning;  blazing fires, open patios, absolutely love the ambiance here in the Arizona sunshine.   Both my husband and I had eggs/bacon dishes- hubby said the hash browns are "to die for", so don't miss these.  Service was friendly and efficient and our breakfast arrived in just minutes.  Coffee was kept full and we were quite happy with our experience.  It's on the Biltmore property, so expect to pay a little more, ~$45 for two.  Worth it.

A great place for casual eats at the Arizona Biltmore. Our waitress, Justine, made the experience so memorable. Her bubbly personality and enthusiasm made us feel at home. 

The cauliflower steAk was ok but nothing exciting and kind of mushy.

The pretzels with beer cheese were great!

The chicken tortilla soup was bomb!

The shaved Brussel sprout salad was more of a slaw but delicious. 

All in all a good experience.

These reviews are based on happy hour only.  Of the six times I've been here over the last year or so, the first four were four-star worthy and fun, all similar to my initial review below.  The last two times have left me pining, whining, wanting more.  The food has lost some of its luster, slightly dry and uninteresting to the palate (save the calamari, which was still quite good).  The service has become typical, with increasingly distracted and mediocre bartenders.  Come on F&A!  Make me re-re-review you back up a star!

We ate here twice during our stay at the Biltmore, both for lunch and we left full and happy after both visits!

This is the casual restaurant on site, and offers indoor dining areas, a covered patio and outdoor patio as well, for those that like to watch kitchen action, one dining area offers stadium views of the kitchen. TV available in the dining area around the bar. So basically you can pick to suit your mood.

Seated outside where we could enjoy the weather and the view, our service was friendly, efficient and paced to match our wind-down mode. We enjoyed a glass of white and rose with the mind blowing soft pretzel and cheese dip as well as the salad and sandwich choices. 

The wine list is wallet friendly and offers a variety of reds, whites and rose, and the menu has something for all.

They also serve breakfast if you prefer sit down to the cafe or room service.

Nice place!

I was excited to go here for breakfast on Saturday and wish I would have spent my money somewhere else. The buffet was something I wouldn't expect from the Biltmore it was extremely disappointing. It felt like a Holiday inn buffet but they did have an omelette chef. The bacon quality was not great and it was swimming in inches of grease the fruit looked bad. For $24 it was worth about $10. For $30 make your way to the Four Seasons Scottsdale for the weekend buffet and you will be blown away double the size with great specialty items. The view alone is worth the drive. Maybe they could take a lesson from them. Service was good but the food was not.

We went the other night for dinner before fireworks.  The food tasted fine however the service was horrendous! And since we can go to so many other places in town for great food AND great service why go back!!?  The server had been there for 3 mos. (that seems like a long enuf time to get acclimated?!) He didn't listen to a word any of us said! We'd say one thing and he'd do another! Our food came out wrong & at different times! It was ridiculous!! We will not be going back!!  Surprising for a restaurant located in a world class resort to be so lousy!!  The Biltmore should be ashamed!!

It's not often that I would give a resort restaurant a good review.  Probably because we usually stray from them because they are often a billion dollars by the time you leave the place.

We decided upon dinner here while staying at the Biltmore for the Hell City Convention.  Since we live in town, I know the area pretty well so our options were anything in the Biltmore area or Frank & Alberts.  I had passed by the menu earlier and figured we'd try it.

We showed up about 6-7ish for dinner and there was no wait, but plenty of people inside.   We were nicely sat right next to the kitchen and almost instantly our drink orders were taken by the smiling Elizabeth. After our drinks we ordered our food and within 20min, our food was out.

While waiting for our food they gave us some bread and a couple dips that were delicious.  One was a chipotle ketchup and the other was a green olive aole type drip.  Both great.  We ordered some onion rings that came stacked in a nice formation along with some buttermilk ranch.  We all ate a few of those, but had saved more for later.

it was dinner time..  

One of our friends had eaten so he grabbed a dessert that he said was one of the best he's ever eaten.  My girlfriend and I ordered the prime rib.  For $25, I thought this was a great price for such a fancy establishment.   I haven't had this tasty of a prime rib cut in a long time.  Every bite was better than the next.  Along with that was a huge piece of broccoli and a nicely cooked baked potato.  The meal was amazing.

But the meal was just a part of it..  Our server Elizabeth would always drop by to make sure we had what we needed.  They were so on top of things, if they over heard us comment on something, they would rush over to make sure we had it.  The staff was ridiculously nice and even the chef came out to check on our food.  I don't think I've ever had a better experience at a restaurant like  I did here.   Frank & Alberts knows food and knows how to take care of their customers.  Well done.

We loved this place so much that we werent here three times during our stay this past weekend.

Very friendly wait staff tended to our every need. Had a nice table outside by the fire for a relaxing casual dinner.  Caesar salad was excellent, as was the "famous" tortilla soup.  The Traditional Pizza with pepperoni, sausage and ham was great. Meal was so good we had a "repeat" served at the bar two nights later!

I honestly cannot understand how some restaurants can feel good about being open.   Today I took my family to Frank & Alberts for my dads 77th birthday.   

We have small children, 8 and 6, so we ordered wine for us and their food.   40 minutes later the Food was brought out.   The Wien came about 20 minutes after that.   

In truth, the food was fine but took forever.    The server was in the weeds and to management's discredit, he was left to his own devices to try and get caught up.   

Since I am here for a week, probably have to try again but not looking forward to it.

This was not a pleasant experience. The hotel was over run with 900 hospitality event attendees filling every nook and cranny with loud conventioneers. The restaurant was noisy so we asked the hostess to seat us in a quieter spot. She took us to a table right in the middle....probably the loudest spot in there. We then asked our waitress to move us which she did.
The food is expensive but that is to be expected for the Biltmore.  But it is over priced for the quality and the small portions. My crab cake BLT was $18 and was cold and greasy. The fries were the saving grace, being crisp and delicious.
T. Cooks at Royal Palm or  Elements at The Sanctuary are far better hotel restaurant alternatives. I would not go back.

Bloody Mary comes with garnish of salami, pepperoncini, big shrimp, olive and a mozarella ball.  Ya, I'll take this over a celery.  

Pass on the celery ceaser salad...good idea, not so good on taste.  Everything else was delicious.
First of service is slow.  Food was ok but over priced.  Lastly make sure you check your bill cuz they automatically add 18% gratuity to it.

Ate here tonight for the first time in ages. I really enjoyed this place. The service was great and the food was wonderful. We had a calamari appetizer, which was breaded with panko. Very good although the dipping sauce was a little ketchup-y. Probably wouldn't order it again. Had the tortilla soup-fabulous and one of the best I've ever had. We also had a duck and goat cheese pizza which was awesome and the crust was perfect. There's a lot of kvetching on here about the prices, but this is a high end resort so what do you expect?

Would love to see them offer healthy options.  Whole wheat pasta, salads with lite dressings and more vegetarian vegan options would be great!   The biscuits with sausage gravy, shake and bake pork, double stuffed potatoes and pizza are great, but will kill you eventually.

Had a great prime rib dinner on friday night.  Ordered rare and it was perfect.  The service was a little slow.  We were seated quickly but it took a long time to have someone come by and get our drink order.  The table across from us came later and got drinks before we even ordered ours.
Good menu with lots of options.  Service was fast and friendly.  It was a hot day and there was plenty of shade and misters to keep it cool.
They have the best pork chops and hamburgers I've ever eaten! Servers are nice. John was very friendly and personable. This place is my go-to for a hot date.

Frank & Alberts is on-site at the Arizona Biltmore Hotel so you're probably coming here because your company is paying for your room and you don't have a car.

Lucky for you it's delicious. Service was great, food was great, drinks were great so everything is great.

When I was in my room I noticed that they had a short rib mac & cheese on the room service menu. I got a hankering for this mac & cheese so when we came to the restaurant to eat I expected it to be on the menu, however it was not. Guess what? They made it for me anyway. It was delicious.

The cheesecake is made in house and I highly recommend it. You should come here.

I've eaten here twice and both times had the most amazing salad-- the A&H, which is a cabbage slaw with BBQ chicken and nuts. It's just the right combinations of sweet and crunchy and still light. My husband had the Caesar with Shrimp and no croutons (he's on Atkins) and to his delight they have fried Parmesan crisps so he could still get some crunch without breaking his diet. Sit out on the indoor patio which lets you have both the sun and the AC!

We have lived in the Biltmore area for many years but did not go to Wrights or the Coffee Shop because it was not as good as other options.  The rework has been successful.  The Prime Rib in this location is better than the Fountain Bleu in Miami Beach.  Eat in the bar for a relaxed meal and cordial atmosphere.  
The portions are big and the price is more than reasonable.  A wonderful experience.

Stopped in for an awesome beer dinner last night at Frank & Albert's. They were featuring the Stone Brewing Co with this meal, one of my faves so we had to partake. Very decently prices, $45/person for a 5 course meal. Chef Jon was hosting the meal, and he knocked it out of the park. We were greeted in the room but the servers, Chef Jon, and the Stone Brewery rep, and this HUGE charcuterie table, covered with dried fruits, meats from all over, amazing cheese (the mango cheddar was the best!), and all kinds of crackers and bread. We were enjoying it so much and listening to Chef Jon tell us all about his selections to pair with the beer that we nearly filled up on the cheese and meat. Each course was paired perfectly with the beer they were featuring. Chef Jon explained each course perfectly and added the highlights of where the product came from, most everything was locally grown, very cool! The main course was the whole roasted pig that was on display all night. Chef's knife skills were truly on display with this task, I think he broke the animal down in less than 20 min, ready to serve, he put on quite a show. The main dish was served with espresso infused forbidden rice, colorful veggies, house made apple sauce and gravy. Each perfect. I said to my friend, the sign of a great chef is when there is no need for salt or pepper on anything, and this hit the spot! I have never participated in a beer dinner or a chef hosted dinner before, this was so much fun. Nice to get to know the chef and his take on food and how he prepares. It's obvious he is in the right field, food is his life, and rightful so. I am excited to see more from him in the future.
Food is really good but expensive. They were going under renovations when we visited but everything was still working. Service was a little slow but workable. Nicely decorated, decent ambiance.

The breakfast here was amazing - wonderful oatmeal with cherry brulee.  The breakfast buffet was also excellent.  However, I give this restaurant two stars because of the dinner we had the night prior to the great breakfast.  The signature lemon lavender martini was very disappointing, as they were fresh out of lavender so they brought me a basic lemon drop martini.  The waiter highly hyped the lemon chicken that came with the "best mashed potatoes he'd ever had", so I ordered that.  The chicken (which was claimed to have been marinated in lemon all night long) had zero lemon taste to it.  Zero.  It was simple rotisserie chicken - good flavor but not what it claimed to me.  The mashed potatoes - I took one bite and without saying anything about them I had my fiance taste them.  His reaction was, "they taste like instant potatoes", which was exactly my thought!!!!!!  I was stunned since they were so hyped.  If I stay at the Biltmore again I definitely would not eat dinner here - I would try the nicer restaurant on the property or go off property.

I was a little underwhelmed by this place.  

I will say that knowing the price of the food and this places location I was expecting an amazing restaurant.  When I walked in however I could tell that the place hasn't received a makeover in quite some time.  The fabric on the seats was all worn out and the interior didn't seem very fresh, seems like it could use a little TLC.

That being said...the food was good.  Split a flat bread, fries, and a queso dip with my cousin.  All three items were tasty. The fries are the only thing that really stick out to me as they were fried in duck fat, which was truly amazing.  I also had a gin and tonic that was mixed very well.  The service was also very good. 

The only reason I am giving the place only two stars is really the price.  I dont feel like the food necessarily lived up to the price. Luckily I was there with someone who had a gift certificate.

I'd like to give 3.5 stars. It's not just "A-OK" but it's not exactly my first choice either.

We were treated to dinner here last night by boyfriend's visiting aunt and her S.O.

- The atmosphere was very nice; we sat in the room with the "Great Glass Fireplace" in the center and floor-to-ceiling windows all around, with a view of the fountain.
- They offered local craft beer selections (including Nimbus, Oak Creek and Four Peaks - yay!) at a reasonable $6.
- Extensive dessert menu; none of this 4 or 5 choices, this thing was a whole page by itself.
- The dark chocolate brulee was (I should say is, I'm eating the leftovers right now) AMAZING. Sugar burnt perfectly, like when you toast the edge of a marshmallow, rich dark chocolate, raspberries. So good!


Negatives:
- Menu was pretty limited - fine dining restaurants are usually limited, but not with a bunch of relatively boring options; their limited offerings usually  have enough interesting twists that you can find SOMETHING that jumps out at you. Not here. Fried chicken and mac and cheese and meatloaf? Odd. 
- My entree (the trout) and boyfriend's (pasta with shrimp) were just OK. The trout and shrimp were cooked nicely but the flavors lacked something. Maybe more lemon on mine? It did refer to it as "braised lemon"...
- Service was a little awkward - the waitress asked if she could start us off with some waters and we all said "Uh... sure?"  It wasn't the water offering, it was that it was like she was selling us on the waters instead of real drinks. She didn't seem to really know anything about the menu either - she went around the table and her description of each of our orders was that they were very good or really popular. I was amused that she was treating me as the "Alpha 'of the table - guess I was intimidating, heehee.
- $6 for a domestic draft is pushing it, especially with craft beers being the same price.
- Bathrooms are light years and eons away, OUTSIDE of the restaurant. Weird.

The food here is only slightly better than Denny's, but at resort prices.  My fried buffalo chicken sandwich was not fully cooked in the middle and the fried mac & cheese app was barley warm and a little soggy.  The kitchen staff seemed irritated that I sent the chicken back - they have an open kitchen so I could see the reaction of the chef when my waitress returned the chicken.

The restaurant was not busy on the Saturday afternoon that I visited, but the hostess was MIA when my party arrived.  We waited for about five minutes before I asked a server in the dinning room to get the hostess to seat my party and the party that had arrived before us.  Really not acceptable.  Our waitress, however, was very friendly and attentive.

I'm a local, so I won't be returning to Frank & Albert's; I think the only people that eat here are those staying at the resort, convenience is really the only reason to go here.

This place is hit or miss.  Not bad for a hotel restaurant but expensive for what you get.  I was here for a conference for a week and had to eat here about 6 times.  2 of the 6 meals were good.  The best was the pizza.  I would only eat here if you are staying here and can not get out.

Frank and Al's is a nice place, it really is.  It's probably too classy in fact.  In exchange for the right to stay in the bar, Frank and Al reciprocate with prices that are ten to twenty percent too high.  I left after an hour spending close to a hundred dollars.  For that I ate nachos with chicken, three beers and two shots of high end booze.  Was it worth it? Depends.   I'll probably never go back because I live far away.  If I lived here I wouldn't go back because I tend to drink too much.  Quick summary, drunks stay away.

We are staying at the Arizona Biltmore and our package comes with lunch and dinner. Our certificates have allowed us to eat VERY well and not exceed our 'allowance'. The outdoor seating is great, especially near the fireplace. We would highly recommend the Tortilla Soup and the Rotisserie Chicken Salad for lunch and we enjoyed many great dinner entrees. Even thought it isn't on the menu, ask for the Falling Water drink....yum!!!!

What a great way to spend Easter morning!

After taking part in the egg hunt on the main grounds (and BTW, they know how to do it here: Massive dumps of eggs full of goodies. More than the kids could carry. Plenty of photo ops. Parents who weren't acting out scenes from Soylent Green.) we made our way to this nicely upscale coffee shop/casual dining spot. 

We were seated 30 minutes ahead of our reservation, keeping my little guy from popping a gasket. I chose the $19 breakfast buffet, and considering it included a custom-made omelette with organic ingredients--as well as juice and coffee--it was a steal. 

Service was wonderful and the staff was sure to make us feel at home. Well, actually better than home because I don't have people looking after my every whim and need while at home.

As the famous Biltmore brunch was not available (remodeling the dining room) this was our next runner up - at $20 the breakfast buffet was a steal for such high quality ingredients. The Bloody Mary was no slouch at $9 either.

Great looking restaurant located inside the Biltmore resort. It's their more casual restaurant compared to Wrights.  It's a great place to have a few apps or meal after sipping on too many Martinis at the Wright Bar.  The staff is pleasant and right on top of your next drink order.  The few times we've dined here we've had delicious food but their menu does change.  The have the coolest looking bread sticks that resemble wheat stalk and is always paired with lip smacking dips that are unique and robust in flavors.  We had the pork empanadas and risotto ravioli. All was super delicious.  A great place to sit back and unwind and enjoy who you're with.

Let's see ... The restaurant is great & the famous architecture is a nice touch for the scenery. The food is very average. Caesar salad was covered with too much dressing and the sea bass was too well done. Coconut custard pie for dessert wasn't bad. I would still suggest coming to check out the Biltmore where Frank and Alberts is located. It's worth the trip to see this famous property.

Sad to say, nothing impressive here. I had family staying at the Biltmore so we ate here. A tasteless hamburger similar to Fry's grocery store meat. Salad was no different then anywhere. I don't know where the reviewers normally eat but this place has nothing special to offer.

I had dinner at Frank and Alberts when my family came to visit and stayed at the Biltmore. Great service and a nice atmosphere. The food received mixed reviews by our table. Three people in our party ordered the caesar salad after the waiter highlighted it. Their special twish was celery, which we all assumed was mixed in for extra crunch. It turns out the entire salad is shaved celery. The celery was just way too stringy and fibrous to really enjoy, plus it watered down the flavor of the caesar dressing. Nice attempt at a twist, but I would say leave that classic alone. 

On the positive side, I did really enjoy the burger - great flavor and the homemade chipotle ketchup was awesome (they also have homemade tarragon mustard). My cousin had the meatloaf which looked amazing. He's a 6'2' 16 year old athlete with a refined palate... I didn't even have a chance to ask for a bite before he devoured it, but he said it was awesome. 

My experience here was good (hence the A-OK rating), but didn't leave me wanting come back for more. What did, however, was their happy hour menu: lots of great looking deals for $5. I'll have to head over for hh and will update my review.

This wonderful Frank Lloyd Wright inspired restaurant sits at the Arizona Biltmore hotel. Walk right in and you'll be taken into a time capsule where Frank Lloyd Wright ruled the architectural century. The floors, furniture, ceiling, menu, even down to the color temperature this place will take you back in time and make you feel like you're inside one of the FLW case study houses. Sit in the lobby, close your eyes
Now on to the food- everything was lovely. The chicken sandwich was great, the fries were good but could have used another dash of salt. Tomato soup and grilled cheese were also a great choice. I'd love to come back here next time I'm visiting Arizona.

Family dinner out on the patio by the fireplace on a perfect March evening can't get much better then that but wait! there's more.  We ordered calamari for an appetizer. It was perfectly fried not greasy at all with a side of  delicious cocktail sauce. I ordered a small organic caesar you get a choice of celery root or organic regular. I chose the celery and it was delicious, perfect portion. If you like more lettuce then get the regular caesar. Then I ordered the chicken and goat cheese desert flat bread pizza. It was more than I could eat but I sure tried to finish it. It was delicious nice moist chicken with the tang of the goat cheese and sweet figs. The desert flat bread was a nice alternative to a regular pizza dough. Great combination of ingredients. All in all a great experience! Katy was our server she was attentive but not breathing down our necks. I cant' wait to go back!

We are staying at the Biltmore, so Frank & Albert's will see us many times during our 4 night stay.

Spinach salad - Very good.  It came with a ton of cranberries and walnuts.  No skimping here.  I would order it again.
Pretzel appetizer - The cheese was great, but the pretzel was a pretzel bread and too dense.  I would not order this again.
Steak & Eggs - Flat Iron steak was cooked perfectly and tasted great.  Eggs were cooked perfectly as well.  I would definitely get this again.

Chicken and waffles - The chicken was great.   The corn puree was excellent.   The waffles were good.  3 waffles and 2 pieces of chicken.   The jalapeno maple syrup is a little spicy. If you're not big eaters,  you can split it with a small side.  

French toast - 4 pieces.   You can get a side dish and split everything.   It was OK.  I'd go with the chicken and waffles instead.

We had two amazing lunches and dinners here during a 3 day stay at The Biltmore. Everything was just perfect from service  to the food. They accommodated plant based/gluten free without a second thought; the servers and chef were very knowledgeable. The brussel sprout/cauliflower salad was exceptional!! Don't miss the table side s'mores! Everything was just fabulous.

The atmosphere is great but the food is pricey and it is a little more than OK but not great. They do have happy hour drinks but not on all food items. We came here mainly to see the architecture of Frank Lloyd Wright.

I have had a great experience every time I have been there.  The food is hard to beat and the service was pleasant.  

Portions are reasonable, not huge (I'm a big feller), and I was satified every time I ate there.  

Very pleasant environment, clean, spacious and calm.

So we ate here twice-Dinner was pretty much terrible. I had a salad that was beyond bland with basically no dressing. My entree was the short rib. It was about 2 oz of meat and attached was a 3 oz blob of fat. Pretty gross! Breakfast- a little better but tiny portions with burnt potatoes. I'm being king with the 2 star....

Very good. They have wonderful food there. I had a great corned beef sandwich and Steven M was a super waiter. For dinner I had their prime rib which was a great deal for $21 with a big baked potato and broccoli and then a chocolate chip cookie for lunch, our server Zach was a very nice guy ad did a great job. Kudos to the Biltmore

My mother in law hosted my baby shower at Frank & Alberts. The atmosphere was perfect. We were given the outside area where they had two long tables set up around the fire pit. It was January so we did have the fire pit on and it was a nice touch. There were roses on the tables along with a couple of flower arrangements. It looked beautiful!

We had pre-selected a couple of menu items, but most people opted for the brunch. As far as brunches go, it was just average. There were several choices, but it was limited for the price. I did like the made to order omelet bar and fresh fruit.

I give them 4 stars because they were friendly and did such a nice job with the set up for my shower. However, if I had only gone for brunch, it would likely be more of a 3 star experience.

Ate here for the TG holiday. I always give folks a pass on the holiday, so giving it 3 stars, not 2. Not up to Waldorf snuff. Food was ok. The tortilla soup was good, but it came out 20 minutes earlier than my husband's soup. 
Did the buffet for the holiday. Food was decent but was barely warm. Our waiter came by often but never cleared any plates. He kept rushing us to the buffet, trying to get us to get our mains before we got our soup, etc. 
we had our menus and two courses finished with plates still on the table. He asked it he could drop the bill when my husband ordered coffee. When he brought the coffee, he told us it was the last cup and he was brewing another and he could get us to go cups with the fresh batch. The stale cup was full of coffee grounds. We were so disappointed, we just tabbed out and left since he kept hurrying us. 
Was a $230 tab for fixed price meal, wine, coffee and auto-grat. 
Was disappointed because it was also our anniversary. Shit meal.

1 stars because of the service. I ordered the chicken and the inside was raw! The guac was old and fries were soggy. For a 5 star hotel the quality of the food was nothing short of a disgrace! I only hope I don't get salmonella poisoning. Frank Lloyd Wright would not be happy if he was still around !

Ate here three times based on a Fodor's review of the tortilla soup, but found that the whole dining experience was below average at best.  3 things made it average to below average.  My order was mixed up 2 of the 3 times I dined there.  The quality of food (in particular the tortilla soup) was just okay-again only average.  Also, the service was slow, though they seemed to have ample staff.  Those are the cons that make me rate it as only 2 stars (and trust me, living in the Biltmore neighborhood the location was convenient where I wanted to love it).

What is exceptional about the restaurant were the grounds surrounding it.  The architecture and design is what you would expect from Frank Lloyd Wright-excellent with sharp lines and open design :).  Check out Taliesen in Scottsdale if you want the Frank Lloyd Wright experience!

Very open and beautiful ambiance. I like patio dining and scenery while eating. 

The best thing I remember was the oil and bread. They offered like 3 different spice mixes. My favorite was the oil and pesto.
